user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_sync:
```c
int lfs_file_sync(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_sync(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)file);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    err = lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_sync -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_sync:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
static int lfs_file_sync_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_ERRED) {
        // it's not safe to do anything if our file errored
        return 0;
    }

    int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
    if (err) {
        file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
        return err;
    }


    if ((file->flags & LFS_F_DIRTY) &&
            !lfs_pair_isnull(file->m.pair)) {
        // before we commit metadata, we need sync the disk to make sure
        // data writes don't complete after metadata writes
        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            err = lfs_bd_sync(lfs, &lfs->pcache, &lfs->rcache, false);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }
        }

        // update dir entry
        uint16_t type;
        const void *buffer;
        lfs_size_t size;
        struct lfs_ctz ctz;
        if (file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE) {
            // inline the whole file
            type = LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT;
            buffer = file->cache.buffer;
            size = file->ctz.size;
        } else {
            // update the ctz reference
            type = LFS_TYPE_CTZSTRUCT;
            // copy ctz so alloc will work during a relocate
            ctz = file->ctz;
            lfs_ctz_tole32(&ctz);
            buffer = &ctz;
            size = sizeof(ctz);
        }

        // commit file data and attributes
        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &file->m, LFS_MKATTRS(
                {LFS_MKTAG(type, file->id, size), buffer},
                {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_FROM_USERATTRS, file->id,
                    file->cfg->attr_count), file->cfg->attrs}));
        if (err) {
            file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
            return err;
        }

        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_DIRTY;
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined all provided functions and macros for assignments that modify function parameter variables (the pointer values themselves). No code assigns to the formal parameters (no statements like lfs = ..., file = ..., head = ..., node = ...). The following points justify that no fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8:

- lfs_file_sync: calls macros and lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file) and returns; it does not assign to the parameters lfs or file.
- lfs_file_sync_: modifies the objects pointed-to by parameters (e.g., file->flags, file->ctz) which is allowed by the rule; it does not reassign the pointer parameters themselves.
- lfs_mlist_isopen: iterates with for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; ...). Taking &head yields the address of the local copy of the parameter; the code updates p (a local pointer-to-pointer) but never assigns to head itself or to node. No parameter is modified.
- Macros (LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE, LFS_ASSERT) are no-ops or call assert and do not modify the pointer parameters passed into the functions.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that violate or require investigation under Rule 17.8 (modifying function parameters).
